lines: Sorry, you're still too young for this experience.  Come back later.
Sorry, you're too old for this experience.
You and ${loverName} are both thinking through your decisions about going to college. ${loverName} wants to go to a college that has a strong pre-veterinary program. There are none in the area.
Making that college would mean that she would need to travel a great distance. You wouldn't see each other for long periods of time. Which one of these things reflects your feelings on this?
Sure you are angry. Who wouldn't be? As a result of your anger, will you:
#TRY TO CONVINCE HER TO STAY HOME
#TRY TO CONVINCE YOURSELF TO BE MORE SUPPORTIVE
This leads to ${loverName} resenting you. Even if the relationship survives her final decision, it will ultimately break down because you seem to want to control her life.

That is very admirable. People sometimes believe they can prevent their anger from surfacing at times like this. That's not possible. Anger is a natural response to loss; and ${loverName} going away to college would certainly qualify
as that. You chose to try to understand your anger as opposed to trying to chain ${loverName} down.

Your relationship may not survive the distance and all the changes college will bring, but you are growing up to be the type of person who will ultimately succeed at finding a good partner to share life with.

Your ambivalence pulls you in two directions at once. You want to please yourself by having ${loverName} with you; and you want to please ${loverName} by supporting her decision to go away to college. This is not something that you can work out
It is a difficult problem to resolve. Think about it: Is it worth trying to tie ${loverName} down close to you if it means the possibility that she will resent you for it later on?

It seems as though you are trying to avoid your real feelings. There is hesitancy and confusion that you are not owning up to. How good could anyone feel after his girl friend has just said she is leaving to go far away for
a relatively long period of time?
